hints_html: Finding the derivative of \(f(x) = 2x + 1\) at \(x = 0\) is the same as finding \(f'(0)\).

hints_raw: Finding the derivative of <math>f(x) = 2x + 1</math> at <math>x = 0</math> is the same as finding <math>f'(0)</math>.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
We are trying to find \(f'(a)\) where \(f(x) = 2x + 1\) and \(a = 0\). Using the first definition of the derivative, we need to know \(f(0)\) which we calculate here:

\(\displaystyle f(0) = 2(0) + 1 = 1\)

Plugging this, and \(f(x)\) into the definition of the derivative, we get:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(0) &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{f(x) - f(0)}{x - 0} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2x + 1 - 1}{x} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2x}{x} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0} 2 \\ &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

We are trying to find \(f'(a)\) where \(f(x) = 2x + 1\) and \(a = 0\).

Using the second definition of the derivative, we will need to know \(f(a + h)\) and \(f(a)\). Since \(a = 0\), they are as follows:

\(\displaystyle f(0 + h) = 2 (0 + h) + 1 = 2h + 1\)

\(\displaystyle f(0) = 2(0) + 1 = 1\)

Plugging these into our definition we get:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(0) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(0 + h) - f(0)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{2h + 1 - 1}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{2h}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} 2 \\ &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Given a differentiable function \(\displaystyle f\), recall that there are two definitions for \(\displaystyle f'(a)\) :

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x - a}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}\end{aligned}\]

Use one of the definitions given to find the derivative of the function \(f(x) = 2x + 1\) at \(x = 0\).
